Award.AwardTitle: Fouling Resistant Ultrafiltration Membranes: Effect of Additive Polymer Architecture

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1437772
Asatekin

Fouling Resistant Ultrafiltration Membranes: Effect of Additive Polymer Architecture

This project will be focused on understanding how the fouling resistance of ultrafiltration membranes is affected by complex feed waters, for example in wastewater treatment. The project team will leverage this knowledge to design and test membranes for wastewater treatment that resist fouling in environments with high fouling potential, such as simulated municipal and industrial wastewater. This project will introduce novel fouling resistant ultrafiltration membranes and provide insights into how they behave in the presence of complex feeds, specifically demanding water streams such as municipal wastewater, littoral seawater, and fracking and produced water. These results will enable more efficient separations in biopharmaceutical, food and beverage industries, and lead to new approaches to bio-fouling prevention in biomedical devices and marine vessels. Graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in this research and they will gain interdisciplinary knowledge and skills, and disseminate the work through publications and presentations.

This project aims to understand how the fouling resistance of ultrafiltration membranes with zwitterionic copolymer additives is affected by complex feeds found in domestic and industrial wastewater treatment, and by the chemical structure and architecture of the zwitterionic additive. It also aims to clarify the fouling resistance mechanisms of zwitterions with different foulants using a combination of filtration and interaction force measurements. This project will focus on ultrafiltration membranes manufactured using non-solvent induced phase separation by blending an amphiphilic zwitterionic copolymer into the casting solution. The project is not only to study the fouling properties of zwitterion-containing membranes, but also to gain a fundamental understanding of the fouling resistance mechanism using surface analysis, interaction force measurements, and physicochemical data. Previous research suggests that zwitterionic surface functionalities impart fouling resistance to filtration membranes, and zwitterion-containing additives in ultrafiltration membrane casting mixtures improve membrane flux. But there is a significant knowledge gap in understanding the fouling resistance of membranes containing different chemical structures and configurations of zwitterionic groups, and how fouling of this class of membranes is affected by feed composition. Hence, this research is potentially transformative for membrane manufacturers and users in wastewater treatment, seawater pretreatment for desalination, and biotech applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Membranes are a crucial technology for energy-efficient, highly effective treatment of water and wastewater. However, the presence of organic compounds, particulates and microrganisms in water streams fed to these membranes leads to fouling, or performance loss due to the accumulation of these materials on the membrane surface. This can be partially prevented by functionalizing the membrane surface with groups that prevent the adsorption of these foulants. In particular, zwitterionic groups, which feature equal numbers of positively and negatively charged moieties, are known to be highly resistant to fouling. This project aimed to develop highly fouling-resistant membranes for treating water and wastewater streams using zwitterionic copolymer additives blended with a commodity polymer, and to better understand how copolymer structure and architecture affected membrane performance. In addition, we aimed to study the performance of these membranes in treating complex feed streams such as saline, oily wastewater. 

For this purpose, we synthesized many zwitterionic amphiphilic copolymers, blended them with the commodity polymer poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), and prepared ultrafiltration (UF) membranes from their mixtures. We first focused on random copolymer additives synthesized from a zwitterionic monomer and methyl methacrylate (MMA), known to be compatible with PVDF. We found that is these additives are designed well, they lead to 3-5 times increased membrane permeability and complete resistance to irreversible fouling by protein solutions and oil suspensions. Furthermore, the super-hydrophilic nature of zwitterions allows this effect to be observed at as little as 5% additive content. Interestingly, if the additive has a high ratio of zwitterionic monomers, surface modification is unsuccessful due to phase separation between PVDF and the additive. These findings enabled us to formulate design rules for zwitterionic polymer additives for membranes, and propose a simple thermal analysis approach to screen additives. 

We also studied the effect of copolymer architecture on additive performance. For this purpose, we synthesized comb-shaped copolymers with a hydrophobic, PVDF-compatible backbone and zwitterionic side-chains. Copolymer compositions that were not water-soluble were used as membrane additives. Both random and comb copolymer additives led to similarly improved flux, whereas comb copolymer led to further improved fouling resistance. Interestingly, membranes prepared with the comb copolymer additive exhibited significant surface rearrangement upon exposure to saline water, resulting in further improved hydrophilicity but decreased flux and pore size. These results call for further exploration of intermolecular interactions between zwitterionic chains on the membrane surface and their effect on membrane performance.

This project was expanded through an international collaboration supplement, which enabled our group to work with Prof. Zeynep Culfaz-Emecen and her lab at the Middle East Technical University (METU) in Turkey on developing responsive polymer nanogels for cake layer removal and on testing the application of membranes developed in Asatekin lab in textile wastewater treatment. Through this collaboration, the PI and an undergraduate researcher traveled to Turkey to work with faculty and students, get trained in new methods, and train students there on polymer synthesis. Two M.S. students from METU also came to Tufts for three weeks to work in the PI's lab. Prof. Culfaz-Emecen also visited Tufts to give a seminar, work with the PI and her team, and discuss future collaborations with other faculty. This led to extensive opportunities for Tufts students to build their skills in international, cross-cultural collaborations.

In addition to these scientific findings, this project enabled several undergraduate and graduate students to acquire research, collaboration, and mentorship skills and build a multidisciplinary skill set. Part of this research was integrated into team projects as part of a core lab class for chemical engineering seniors at Tufts each year. The PI also incorporated the research into her teaching, including a required course on Chemical and Biological Separations and two polymer science electives.

The PI participated in many activities to encourage broader participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields, including Women in Engineering Open House events held by Tufts for high school students, presentations to 1st generation and minority students in the Bridge to Engineering Success at Tufts (BEST) program, panels organized by Tufts and MIT chapters of Society of Women Engineers, and Path to Professorship Workshops organized for women interested in academic careers in STEM organized at Northeastern University and MIT. The research led to several journal articles, and was presented at conferences including NAMS, ACS and AIChE meetings. It also led to several patent applications, including two that are in negotiations for licensing, demonstrating a path to broader impacts of this work through commercialization.


Last Modified: 12/13/2018
Modified by: Ayse Asatekin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Membranes are a crucial technology for energy-efficient, highly effective treatment of water and wastewater. However, the presence of organic compounds, particulates and microrganisms in water streams fed to these membranes leads to fouling, or performance loss due to the accumulation of these materials on the membrane surface. This can be partially prevented by functionalizing the membrane surface with groups that prevent the adsorption of these foulants. For this purpose, we synthesized many zwitterionic amphiphilic copolymers, blended them with the commodity polymer poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), and prepared ultrafiltration (UF) membranes from their mixtures. It also led to several patent applications, including two that are in negotiations for licensing, demonstrating a path to broader impacts of this work through commercialization.
